sen.j: 天下人（てんかびと／てんかにん）とは、天下の政権を掌握した人のことをいう。
sen.e: Tenka-bito (or tenka-nin) refers to people who have the world under control.
Tenka-bito (or tenka-nin) refers to the people who controlled the world as they knew it (in this case, the Japanese islands).
sen.cmt: 「天下」を the world で無く、具体的に訳出しました。また、冠詞を補いました。
sen.e: Tenka-bito (or tenka-nin) refers to the people who controlled the world as they knew it (in this case, the Japanese islands).

sen.j: 主に戦国時代 (日本)から江戸時代初期にかけて、琉球（沖縄県）と蝦夷地（北海道）の大半を除く日本全土を自らの支配下に置き、日本全土を統一した者を指す。
sen.e: It refers to people who unified whole of Japan from the Sengoku period to the early Edo period except Ryukyu (Okinawa prefecture) and most areas of Ezochi (Hokkaido) by having it under control.
It refers to the people who unified and controlled the whole of Japan, except Ryukyu (Okinawa prefecture) and most areas of Ezochi (Hokkaido), from the Sengoku period to the early Edo period.
It refers to the people who unified and controlled the whole of Japan, except Ryukyu (Okinawa prefecture) and most areas of Ezochi (Hokkaido), from the Sengoku period to the early Edo period.

sen.j: もともと「天下」とは、世界の全体を指す抽象概念であり、古代中国の思想概念だったものが、日本でも古代から用いられるようになった。
sen.e: "Tenka" is a concept originated from China that referred to the entire world; it has been used in Japan since the ancient times.
"Tenka" is a concept, which originated in China that referred to the entire world; it has been used in Japan since ancient times.
sen.cmt: 冠詞、前置詞を訂正しました。
sen.e: "Tenka" is a concept, which originated in China that referred to the entire world; it has been used in Japan since ancient times.

sen.j: 「天下」という言葉は、蘇我馬子が草創した飛鳥寺の塔の露盤銘で、推古天皇4年（596年）に使用されていることが確認されている。
sen.e: The word "tenka" is seen on the roban (dew basin at the bottom of a pagoda finial) of Asuka-dera Temple established by SOGA no Umako, which confirms that the word was already used in 596.
The word "tenka" is seen on the roban (dew basin at the bottom of a pagoda finial) of Asuka-dera Temple established by SOGA no Umako, which confirms that the word was already used in 596.
The word "tenka" is seen on the roban (dew basin at the bottom of a pagoda finial) of Asuka-dera Temple established by SOGA no Umako, which confirms that the word was already used in 596.

sen.j: それ以降、しきりに用いられ、天皇の支配を「治天下」と表現したりしている。
sen.e: Since then, the word has frequently been used that the government by the emperor is called "chitenka (rule the tenka)."
Since then, the word has frequently been used to the extent that Government of an Emperor is called "chitenka" (rule the tenka).
sen.cmt: to the extent that …を補足しました。引用符の場所を変更しました。
sen.e: Since then, the word has frequently been used to the extent that Government of an Emperor is called "chitenka" (rule the tenka).

sen.j: 「天下人」という言葉がいつ頃出来上がって、誰が使い始めたかは定かではないが、江戸時代初期の元和 (日本)7年（1621年）より書かれた『川角太閤記』が初めてといわれており、この頃にはすでに普及・定着しつつあったことがわかる。
sen.e: It is not certain when the word "tekna jin" has become an established word and who started using it, however, it is said that the first book that this word was mentioned was "Kawasumi Taikoki" written in 1621, and it is thought that this word was already becoming a common word among the people of that time.

It is not certain when the word "tenka-bito" first became an established word or who started using it, however, it is said that the first book in which this word was mentioned was "Kawasumi Taikoki" written in 1621, and it is thought that this word had already become a common word among the people of that time.
sen.cmt: 時制を訂正しました(has become を became に、was already becoming を had already become に)。
sen.e: It is not certain when the word "tenka-bito" first became an established word or who started using it, however, it is said that the first book in which this word was mentioned was "Kawasumi Taikoki" written in 1621, and it is thought that this word had already become a common word among the people of that time.

tit.j: 天下人と見られるための条件
tit.e: Requirements to be considered as tenka-bito
To become a tenka-bito, one should:
tit.cmt: 後に続く条件が、one should に呼応する形にしました。
tit.e: To become a tenka-bito, one should:

sen.j: 天下を掌握する。
sen.e: Has tenka (the world) under control.
Control the tenka (world)
sen.cmt: Controlsを文頭にし、掌握の意味をよりはっきりさせました。
sen.e: Control the tenka (world)

sen.j: 天下人が天下を取った人である以上、当然の条件としていえるが、天下人が取った天下の内容が時代によって一様ではなかった。
sen.e: The conditions of having tenka under cotrol and how it was achieved differ depending on tenka-bito.
sen.cmt: 「天下人が天下を取った人である以上、当然の条件としていえるが」の部分の意味がいまいちよく分からなかったのでで、訳せませんでした。
sen.e: The conditions for achieving the status of tenka-bito differ according to the period and the individual.
sen.cmt: 翻訳者のコメント通りに思います。文面をよりすっきりさせました。
sen.e: The conditions for achieving the status of tenka-bito differ according to the period and the individual.

sen.j: 例えば、源頼朝は、自らの事業を「天下の草創」と称したが、後の豊臣秀吉や徳川家康が日本六十余州を支配したことに比べ、頼朝は比較にならないほどである。
sen.e: For example, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo called his project 'Beginning of a unified country (tenka no shoshi),' however, his governing areas are beyond comparison to the number of prefectures, around 60, that Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA governed.

For example, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo called his project 'Beginning of a unified country (tenka no shoshi),' however, his governing areas cannot be compared with the sixty or so provinces that Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA governed.
sen.cmt: 誤訳（beyond comparison）を訂正しました。
sen.e: For example, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo called his project 'Beginning of a unified country (tenka no shoshi),' however, his governing areas cannot be compared with the sixty or so provinces that Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA governed.

sen.j: しかし、頼朝が天下人と呼ばれるのは、御家人制と呼ばれる個々の武士たちとの主従的結合（御恩と奉公）を通じて、全国に影響力を及ぼすことができたためである。
sen.e: However, the reason Yoritomo was called tenkabito is because he influenced the whole country through the firm master and servant relationship (obligation and service) with each samurai.
However, the reason Yoritomo was called tenka-bito is because he influenced the whole country through the firm master-and-servant relationship (obligation and service) with each samurai.
sen.cmt: master-and-servantを一語にしました。また、tenkabitoいハイフン補足、firm master間の余分な余白を削除しました。
sen.e: However, the reason Yoritomo was called tenka-bito is because he influenced the whole country through the firm master-and-servant relationship (obligation and service) with each samurai.

sen.j: 足利尊氏についても同様のことがいえる。
sen.e: The same thing applies to Takauji ASHIKAGA.
The same thing applies to Takauji ASHIKAGA.
The same thing applies to Takauji ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 織田信長の天下は、頼朝や尊氏、後継者となった秀吉のそれとは違う。
sen.e: The tenka of Nobunaga ODA differs from that of Yoritomo, Takauji, and Hideyoshi, who became his successor.
The tenka of Nobunaga ODA differs from that of Yoritomo, Takauji, and his successor Hideyoshi.
sen.cmt: 後継者の記述を簡潔にしました。
sen.e: The tenka of Nobunaga ODA differs from that of Yoritomo, Takauji, and his successor Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 信長は「織田信長天下布武」のもと、天下統一を志していたが、本能寺の変で急死。
sen.e: Nobunaga was aiming to unify the whole country under 'Nobunaga ODA's unification of Japan,' however, he suddenly died in the Honnoji Incident.
Nobunaga was aiming to unify the whole country under 'Nobunaga ODA's unification of Japan policy,' however, he suddenly died in the Honnoji Incident.
sen.cmt: 「織田信長天下布武」の訳に policy を追記しました。
sen.e: Nobunaga was aiming to unify the whole country under 'Nobunaga ODA's unification of Japan policy,' however, he suddenly died in the Honnoji Incident.

sen.j: その段階では畿内を含む二十数か国の主に留まっていた。
sen.e: At the time his death, he was only had around 20 domains under control.
At the time of his death, he had only around 20 domains under control.
sen.cmt: 前置詞、時制を訂正しました。
sen.e: At the time of his death, he had only around 20 domains under control.

sen.j: しかし、信長が在世中から「天下の主」「天下様」とされていたのは、天下＝日本の中心部、つまり京都を支配下に置いていたことである。
sen.e: The reason he was regarded as 'the master of tenka (tenka no nushi)' or 'Mr. tenka (tenka sama)' is because he had the center of Japan, Kyoto, under his control.
The reason he was regarded as 'the master of tenka (tenka no nushi)' or 'Mr. Tenka (tenka sama)' is because he controlled the center of Japan, i.e. Kyoto.
sen.cmt: because 以下を簡潔にしました。
sen.e: The reason he was regarded as 'the master of tenka (tenka no nushi)' or 'Mr. Tenka (tenka sama)' is because he controlled the center of Japan, i.e. Kyoto.

sen.j: もし、信長が生き長らえていたならば、全国を統一していたに違いない。
sen.e: However, if he did not suddenly in this incident, it is thought he would have unified the whole country.
However, if he had not suddenly died in this incident, it is thought that he would have unified the whole country.
sen.cmt: 時制をを訂正しました。
sen.e: However, if he had not suddenly died in this incident, it is thought that he would have unified the whole country.

sen.j: 武士として政権を立てる。
sen.e: Establish the gocvernment as samurai
Establish of a samurai government
Establish of a samurai government

sen.j: 天下人と呼ばれたのは、いずれも武士である。
sen.e: It was only samurai who were called tanka-jin.
It was only samurai who were called tenka-jin.
It was only samurai who were called tenka-jin.

sen.j: つまり、武力を背景として武家政権を興したものが天下人とされてきた。
sen.e: They were the people who established the samurai government by the military power.
They were the people who established the samurai government by military power.
sen.cmt: the military power の冠詞を削除しました。
sen.e: They were the people who established the samurai government by military power.

sen.j: 朝廷の臣下として振る舞う。
sen.e: Behave as the vassals of the Imperial Court.
Behave as the vassals of the Imperial Court.
Behave as the vassals of the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 天下人は、例外なく朝廷の臣下としての形を取りながら、政治の実権を握った。
sen.e: Tenka-bito took the control of the governement as the vassal of the Imperial Court.
Tenka-bito took control of the government as the vassal of the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: the control の冠詞を削除しました。
sen.e: Tenka-bito took control of the government as the vassal of the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 彼らは天皇家（天皇・治天の君）を頭の上に戴いて事業を進めていたといえる。
sen.e: It can be said that they were developing their project by having the Imperial family as their leader.
It can be said that, by having the Imperial family as their leader, they were in fact running the country.
sen.cmt: developing their project を in face running the country に置き換えました。
sen.e: It can be said that, by having the Imperial family as their leader, they were in fact running the country.

sen.j: 武家政権が出現した頃には、天皇家は次第に権力を失いつつあり、権威だけを保有する方向に向かっていた。
sen.e: When the samurai government appeared, the Imperial family was gradually losing its power that they were only beginning to hold its authority.
As the samurai government came to prominence, the Imperial family was gradually losing its power, to the extent that they had authority but no power.
sen.cmt: appeared を came to prominence に置き換え、 that they were only beginning to hold its authority を to the extent that they had authority but no power に置き換えました。
sen.e: As the samurai government came to prominence, the Imperial family was gradually losing its power, to the extent that they had authority but no power.

sen.j: それでも、天皇家は日本66か国の国主であった。
sen.e: In spite of this change, the Imperial family was the landed daimyo (kokushu) of the 66 domains in Japan.
In spite of this change, the Imperial family was kokushu (Japanese feudal lord who governs more than one province) of the 66 domains in Japan.
sen.cmt: kokushu の説明を補足しました。
sen.e: In spite of this change, the Imperial family was kokushu (Japanese feudal lord who governs more than one province) of the 66 domains in Japan.

sen.j: 朝廷の臣下としての天下人は、征夷大将軍のような武官コースを取る場合と、関白・太政大臣といった文官コースを取る場合とがあったが、それは関係のないことであり、一定のポストに就かなければ天下人と見られないわけではない。
sen.e: Tenka-bito as the vassal of the Imperial Court governed the country in two ways: as a military officer such as Seitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) and as a civil officer such as Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) and Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister); however, to have a certain position was not necessarily a requirement of a tenka-bito.

Tenka-bito as the vassal of the Imperial Court governed the country in two ways: as a military officer such as Seiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) and as a civil officer such as Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) and Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister); however, to holding such a position was not necessarily a requirement of a tenka-bito.
sen.cmt: Seitaishogun のスペルを Seiitaishogun に変更しました。
sen.e: Tenka-bito as the vassal of the Imperial Court governed the country in two ways: as a military officer such as Seiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) and as a civil officer such as Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) and Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister); however, to holding such a position was not necessarily a requirement of a tenka-bito.

sen.j: 頼朝、尊氏、家康は征夷大将軍になっているが、秀吉は関白となる道を選んだ。
sen.e: Yoritomo, Takauji, and Ieyasu all became Seitaishogun, however, Hideyoshi chose to be kanpaku.
Yoritomo, Takauji, and Ieyasu all became Seiitaishogun, however, Hideyoshi chose to be kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor).
sen.cmt: Seiitaishogun のスペル変更と kanpaku の補足説明を加えました。
sen.e: Yoritomo, Takauji, and Ieyasu all became Seiitaishogun, however, Hideyoshi chose to be kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor).

sen.j: 信長の場合、天正3年（1575年）、右近衛大将となり、内大臣、右大臣へと進んだが、その後は無官となっている。
sen.e: As for Nobunaga, he became Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) in 1575 and then became naidaijin (minister of the center) and udaijin (minister of the right), however, after that, he did not hold any position at the government.

As for Nobunaga, he became Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of the Inner Palace Guards) in 1575 and then became naidaijin (Minister of the center) and udaijin (Minister of the right), however, after that, he did not hold any further government positions.
sen.cmt: 冠詞の補足、any position at the government を any further government positions に変更しました。
sen.e: As for Nobunaga, he became Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of the Inner Palace Guards) in 1575 and then became naidaijin (Minister of the center) and udaijin (Minister of the right), however, after that, he did not hold any further government positions.

sen.j: 朝廷から関白・太政大臣・征夷大将軍のいずれかへの推挙をしたいという要望があったくらいである（三職推任問題）。
sen.e: He was even proposed a position of kanpaku, Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister), or seitaishogun from the Imperial Court (the question of the three alternative positions, called Shanshoku suinin mondai).
He was even offered the positions of kanpaku, Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister), or seitaishogun from the Imperial Court (the question of the three alternative positions, called Sanshoku suinin mondai).
sen.cmt: proposed を offered に変更、modai を mondai に訂正しました。
sen.e: He was even offered the positions of kanpaku, Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister), or seitaishogun from the Imperial Court (the question of the three alternative positions, called Sanshoku suinin mondai).

sen.j: 政権が「全国性」を持っている。
sen.e: The government has the power over the whole country.
The government controls the whole country.
sen.cmt: have the power から control に変更、over を除去しました。
sen.e: The government controls the whole country.

sen.j: 天下統一とは、上述の通り、日本全国を統一して一元的に支配することである。
sen.e: As explained above, unification of the whole country means to unify the entire Japan in an integrated fashion.
As explained above, unification of the whole country means to unify the whole of Japan in an integrated fashion.
sen.cmt: the entire Japan を the whole of Japan としました。
sen.e: As explained above, unification of the whole country means to unify the whole of Japan in an integrated fashion.

sen.j: 秀吉と家康の政権は、名実ともに全国政権であった。
sen.e: The governments of Hideyoshi and Ieyasu, both in name and reality, were for the whole country.
The governments of Hideyoshi and Ieyasu, both in name and reality, were in control of the whole country.
sen.cmt: for the whole country を in control of the whole country としました。
sen.e: The governments of Hideyoshi and Ieyasu, both in name and reality, were in control of the whole country.

sen.j: 頼朝の場合、領国的な支配は東国中心であったが、御家人制によって全国的に人を支配していた。
sen.e: Yoritomo mainly ruled Togoku (eastern country), he was also controlling the whole country by the system of gokenin (shogunal retainers).
Yoritomo mainly ruled Togoku (eastern country), he could also control the whole country by the system of gokenin (shogunal retainers).
sen.cmt: he was also controlling を he could also control としました。
sen.e: Yoritomo mainly ruled Togoku (eastern country), he could also control the whole country by the system of gokenin (shogunal retainers).

sen.j: 尊氏になると、南北朝の時代になっており、お互いを正当な政権であると主張していた。
sen.e: At the time of Takauji, it was the period of the Northern and Southern Courts and both were claiming as the legitimate governments, the Northern Court led by the Ashikaga family was always more powerful than the government of the Southern Court ruled by kuge (court nobles) and that they governed Kyoto, which was the center of Japan during that time.
At the time of Takauji, the Northern and Southern Courts both claimed to be the legitimate governments.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処２つに分割しました。
sen.e: At the time of Takauji, the Northern and Southern Courts both claimed to be the legitimate governments.

sen.j: 北朝 (日本)を擁した足利家の武家政権は、終始、公家である南朝 (日本)政権より強力であり、日本の中心部である京都をほぼ支配していた。
sen.e: The Northern Court, led by the Ashikaga family, was always more powerful than the government of the Southern Court ruled by kuge (court nobles) and the Northern court governed Kyoto, which was the center of Japan during that time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Northern Court, led by the Ashikaga family, was always more powerful than the government of the Southern Court ruled by kuge (court nobles) and the Northern court governed Kyoto, which was the center of Japan during that time.

sen.j: 信長の政権も、畿内を含む京都とそこにいる朝廷を押さえていた。
sen.e: The government by Nobunaga was also governing the kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto) and the Imperial Courts of this area.
Nobunaga's government also ruled the kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto) and the Imperial Courts of this area.
sen.cmt: 過去進行形を過去形に訂正し、動詞はruleにしました。
sen.e: Nobunaga's government also ruled the kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto) and the Imperial Courts of this area.

sen.j: その意味においては、全国性を持っていたことになる。
sen.e: In that sense, it is thought that the government had that power over the whole country.
In that sense, it is thought that the government had power over the whole country.
sen.cmt: that power の that を除去しました。
sen.e: In that sense, it is thought that the government had power over the whole country.

tit.j: 天下人になるための条件

sen.j: 天下取りの意欲がある。
sen.e: Be eager to take the reins of the government
Be eager to take the reins of the government
Be eager to take the reins of the government

sen.j: 天下人になるためには、まず天下人になろうという意欲があることである。
sen.e: To become tenka-bito, they must first of all have the will to be one.
First of all, they must have the will to become tenka-bito.
First of all, they must have the will to become tenka-bito.

sen.j: しかし、その意欲がどのくらい強固なものであったかは、別問題である。
sen.e: However, the degree of eagerness is a different matter.
However, the degree of eagerness is a different matter.
However, the degree of eagerness is a different matter.

sen.j: 頼朝にしろ、尊氏にしろ、中央政権（公家政権）とは違う新しい政権を樹立しようという意欲は、その時々の事態が進行してからである。
sen.e: How much one is eager to establish a central administration (the kuge, court nobles, government) depended on how the state of affairs were progressing.
How much one is eager to establish a central administration (the kuge, court nobles, government) depended on how the state of affairs were progressing.
How much one is eager to establish a central administration (the kuge, court nobles, government) depended on how the state of affairs were progressing.

sen.j: また、天下取りという意欲を持てば誰でも天下を望める風潮が出てきたのは、戦国時代になってからのことであった。
sen.e: Also, it was only after the Sengoku period (period of warring states) that the society began showing its attitude of give chances to anyone to rule the tenka as long as they have the wish to do so; among them, only some of them began having the will to do so and also it was only among some of them who actually succeeded in accomplishing this goal.
Also, it was only after the Sengoku period (period of warring states) that the society began showing its attitude of giving a chance to anyone to rule the tenka as long as they had the will to do so.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処、また、giving chances を giving a chance に、they have the wish を they had the will としました。
sen.e: Also, it was only after the Sengoku period (period of warring states) that the society began showing its attitude of giving a chance to anyone to rule the tenka as long as they had the will to do so.

sen.j: それを目指す者の中で何人かの者だけが、ある段階で天下取りへの意欲を持つようになり、そのうちのまた何人かが成功したというのが実情であろう。
sen.e: Few people truly had the will to do so and even fewer actually succeeded in accomplishing this goal.
sen.cmt: 簡潔な文に書き換えました。一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Few people truly had the will to do so and even fewer actually succeeded in accomplishing this goal.

sen.j: 一定の軍事力・経済力を備えている。
sen.e: Has a certain military force and economical power.
Have a certain military force and economical power.
sen.cmt: Has を Have としました。
sen.e: Have a certain military force and economical power.

sen.j: 天下人の政権は、それを樹立するに当たって妨害を排除し、ライバルを圧倒するだけの軍事力がなければ成り立たない。
sen.e: The governement of tenka-bito should have the military power strong enough to eliminate obstacles and overwhelm rivals.
The government of tenka-bito should be strong enough in military terms to eliminate obstacles and overwhelm rivals.
sen.cmt: should have the military power strong enough to を should be strong enough in military terms に変更しました。
sen.e: The government of tenka-bito should be strong enough in military terms to eliminate obstacles and overwhelm rivals.

sen.j: 政権樹立後も、抵抗しようとする者たちを押さえて、これを維持していくための武力が必要である。
sen.e: Even after the establishment of the government, they need the military power to control the rebellious people against their governement.
Even after the establishment of the government, they needed military power to control those who would rebel against their government.
sen.cmt: they need the military power を they needed military power に訂正、 the rebellious people against their governement を those who would rebel against their governement に変更しました。
sen.e: Even after the establishment of the government, they needed military power to control those who would rebel against their government.

sen.j: しかし、その軍事力は、必ずしも自前のものとは限らないし、そうである必要もない。
sen.e: However, this military power was not always their own and did not have to be.
However, this military power was not always their own and did not have to be.
However, this military power was not always their own and did not have to be.

sen.j: 軍事力は数あるいは質の問題なのである。
sen.e: The military power should be evaluated by its amount and quality.
The military power would be evaluated by its amount and quality.
sen.cmt: should を would に変更しました。
sen.e: The military power would be evaluated by its amount and quality.

sen.j: 経済力も天下取りの重要要素である。
sen.e: The economical power is also the important factor of having tanka(tenka) under control.
Economical power was also an important factor in having tenka under control.
sen.cmt: 冠詞と前置詞の訂正、tanka を削除しました。
sen.e: Economical power was also an important factor in having tenka under control.

sen.j: 日本では、経済力は農業生産力、ことに米の生産力が主流である。
sen.e: In Japan, the major economical power is agricultural productivity, particularly, rice production.
In Japan, the major economical power was agricultural productivity, particularly, rice production.
sen.cmt: is を was に訂正しました。
sen.e: In Japan, the major economical power was agricultural productivity, particularly, rice production.

sen.j: 米は貨幣と同様に通用する便利な商品であった。
sen.e: Rice, as well as money, was a convenient commertial product that could be be circulated.
Rice, as well as money, was a convenient commercial product that could be circulated.
sen.cmt: commertial から commercial に訂正しました。
sen.e: Rice, as well as money, was a convenient commercial product that could be circulated.

sen.j: とはいえ、諸大名も将軍も米ばかりを当てにして動いていたわけではない。
sen.e: However, the circulation of rice was not the only goal of the activities of the territorial lords and shogun.
However, the circulation of rice was not the only goal of the activities of the territorial lords and shogun.
However, the circulation of rice was not the only goal of the activities of the territorial lords and shogun.

sen.j: 平清盛は日宋貿易に力を入れていたし、足利義満も日明貿易に熱心だった。
sen.e: TAITRA no Kiyomori was emphasizing the trade between Japan and the Sung Dynasty in China and Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was keen on the trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China.
TAIRA no Kiyomori emphasized trade between Japan and the Sung Dynasty in China and Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was keen on trading between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China.
sen.cmt: was emphasizing the trade を emphasized trade に変更、
sen.e: TAIRA no Kiyomori emphasized trade between Japan and the Sung Dynasty in China and Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was keen on trading between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China.

sen.j: 信長が楽市・楽座のような商工業を重視していたことは有名である。
sen.e: It is well known that Nobunaga was putting emphasis on trade and craft such as rakuichi-rakuza (free markets and open guilds).
It is well known that Nobunaga put great emphasis on trade and craft such as rakuichi-rakuza (free markets and open guilds).
sen.cmt: 重視していた - was putting emphasis を put great emphasis としました。
sen.e: It is well known that Nobunaga put great emphasis on trade and craft such as rakuichi-rakuza (free markets and open guilds).

sen.j: 秀吉は金山・銀山を直轄化しており、豊臣氏が富強であったのはそうした背景があったからだとも言われている。
sen.e: Hideyoshi had gold mine and silver mine under direct control; it is thought this factor helped him remain rich and powerful.
Hideyoshi had gold mines and silver mines under direct control; it is thought this factor helped him remain rich and powerful.
sen.cmt: mine を mines としました。
sen.e: Hideyoshi had gold mines and silver mines under direct control; it is thought this factor helped him remain rich and powerful.

sen.j: 必要な家格・地位などを持っている。
sen.e: Has necessary social standing and status
Have necessary social standing and status
sen.cmt: has を have に変更しました。
sen.e: Have necessary social standing and status

sen.j: 天下人の政権は軍事政権であるといっても、ひたすら武力で支配したいたわけではない。
sen.e: Even if the government of tenka was military, it did not mean they wanted to govern by the military power.
Even though tenka-bito ran a military regime, it did not mean they wanted to govern by military power.
sen.cmt: Even if the government of tenka was military を Even though tenka-bito ran a military regime に変更しました。
sen.e: Even though tenka-bito ran a military regime, it did not mean they wanted to govern by military power.

sen.j: 支配される側に、支配されることへの同意や関心を呼び起こすようなことも考えなければならない。
sen.e: It was necessary to get agreements concerning their states from the subordinates and their interests over this affair.
They had to think about how to look after and motivate their subordinates in order to gain their compliance to rule.
sen.cmt: 訳文を書き換えました。
sen.e: They had to think about how to look after and motivate their subordinates in order to gain their compliance to rule.

sen.j: 政治権力というのは、単なる実体として存在するわけではなく、それに従う者、統治される者との関係において成立するものである。
sen.e: The political force did not exist as an entity; it only existed in the relationship with the controlled.
Political force did not exist as an entity; it only existed in the relationship with the subordinates.
sen.cmt: 不必要な冠詞の除去と、the controlled を the subordinates に置換えました。
sen.e: Political force did not exist as an entity; it only existed in the relationship with the subordinates.

sen.j: ここでいう家格や官位といったものが、支配される者を納得させ、支配される者が自ら納得するための重要な要素の1つであったといえる。
sen.e: It can be thought that the social standing or court rank was one of the important factors that convinced the state of the relationship for both the governor and his subordinates.
It can be thought that social standing or court rank was one of the important factors that cemented the relationship between the governor and his subordinates.
sen.cmt: 不必要な冠詞の除去と、important factors 以下を簡潔に書換えました。
sen.e: It can be thought that social standing or court rank was one of the important factors that cemented the relationship between the governor and his subordinates.

sen.j: 支配する側としては、そうしたものを備えることによって、支配することの正当性を獲得するような形になるのである。
sen.e: Governors can actually justify their reasons for governing by having these attibutes.
Governors could actually justify their reasons for governing by having these attributes.
sen.cmt: can を could に訂正、スペルミスを訂正（attibutes から attributes に）しました。
sen.e: Governors could actually justify their reasons for governing by having these attributes.

sen.j: 頼朝の場合、清和源氏の嫡流であり、八幡太郎義家の玄孫であるという家格があった。
sen.e: Yoritomo was a direct descendant of Seiwa-Genji (the Minamoto clan) and had a social status as great-great-grandson of HACHIMANTARO Yoshiie, and Takauji was the same.
Yoritomo was a direct descendant of Seiwa-Genji (the Minamoto clan) and had a social status as great-great-grandson of HACHIMANTARO Yoshiie.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Yoritomo was a direct descendant of Seiwa-Genji (the Minamoto clan) and had a social status as great-great-grandson of HACHIMANTARO Yoshiie.

sen.j: また、尊氏もまったく同じであった。
sen.e: Takauji was the same.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Takauji was the same.

sen.j: しかし、応仁の乱（1467年～1477年）以降、戦国時代に入ると、下剋上の風潮が高まり、「家格破壊」が実現した。
sen.e: However, in the time of Sengoku period after the Onin War, gekokujo (an inverted social order when the lowly reigned over the elite) became more prevalent and the collapse of family status began to happen.

However, during the Sengoku period after the Onin War (1467-1477), gekokujo (an inverted social order when the lowly reigned over the elite) became more prevalent and the collapse of family status began to happen.
sen.cmt: in the time of を during に変更、応仁の乱の期間を追加しました。
sen.e: However, during the Sengoku period after the Onin War (1467-1477), gekokujo (an inverted social order when the lowly reigned over the elite) became more prevalent and the collapse of family status began to happen.

sen.j: 秀吉はもちろんのこと、信長、家康にしても、その家格は決して高いものではなかった。
sen.e: Not only Hdeyoshi, but also Nobunaga and Ieyasu also did not have high positions.
Not only Hideyoshi, but also Nobunaga and Ieyasu did not have high positions.
sen.cmt: Hideyoshi のスペルミス訂正と、also は不要のため削除しました。
sen.e: Not only Hideyoshi, but also Nobunaga and Ieyasu did not have high positions.

sen.j: 家格破壊の結果、実力さえあれば氏素性の怪しさなどは、黙認された時代になっていた。
sen.e: After the collapse of the family status, there was a trend in the society to overlook their origins as long as they have the ability to rule.
After the collapse of the importance of family status, there was a trend in the society to overlook the origins as long as they have the ability to rule.
sen.cmt: the collapse of the family status を the collapse of the importance of family status としました。
sen.e: After the collapse of the importance of family status, there was a trend in the society to overlook the origins as long as they have the ability to rule.

sen.j: 一定の能力を備えている。
sen.e: Has certain abilities.
Have certain abilities.
sen.cmt: Has を Have に変更しました。
sen.e: Have certain abilities.

sen.j: 歴史を動かすような人たちは、いずれも非凡な才能の持ち主であったかのように考えがちだが、実態は必ずしもそうではない。
sen.e: It is often thought that people who influenced the human history had extraordinary abilities, however, in reality, that was not always the case.
It is often thought that people who influenced human history had extraordinary abilities, however, in reality, that was not always the case.
sen.cmt: 不必要な冠詞を削除しました。
sen.e: It is often thought that people who influenced human history had extraordinary abilities, however, in reality, that was not always the case.

sen.j: 天下を取るほどの人間には、人より優れたものがあったのかもしれないが、天下人以外にも同じ程度の能力を持っていた者は、いくらでもいたに違いない。
sen.e: People who governed the tenka may have had abilities that excelled others, however, at the same time, there should also have been numbers of people who had the same level of abilities.
People who governed the tenka may have had abilities that excelled others, however, at the same time, there must also have been numbers of people who had the same level of abilities.
sen.cmt: 文頭の余分な１スペースを削除しました。また、should を must に置換えました。
sen.e: People who governed the tenka may have had abilities that excelled others, however, at the same time, there must also have been numbers of people who had the same level of abilities.

sen.j: しかし、結果論的評価として、彼らを大政治家、大英雄、大革命家と持ち上げられるようになったのは否めない。
sen.e: However, we cannot deny the fact that we flattered and raised them to the positions of big politicians, heros, and revolutionists.
However, one cannot deny the fact that it is we who flattered and raised them to the positions of big politicians, heroes, and revolutionaries.
sen.cmt: 原文を「いがめない」から「否めない」に訂正しました。また、
sen.e: However, one cannot deny the fact that it is we who flattered and raised them to the positions of big politicians, heroes, and revolutionaries.

sen.j: 運・ツキに恵まれている。
sen.e: Surrounded by good conditions and environement
Be surrounded by good conditions and environment
sen.cmt: Surrounded から Be surrounded に変更しました。
sen.e: Be surrounded by good conditions and environment

sen.j: 天下人が天下人になれた過程をみると、その時々に偶然としかいいようのない出来事や事情の積み重ねが彼らを天下人に押し上げていったことは明白である。
sen.e: If we take a look at the process of someone becoming a tenka-bito, it becomes obvisous that all the circomstances around him and the things happened around him by chance raised him to this position.
Having seen the process of becoming a tenka-bito, it is clear that a combination of circumstances and chance, would raise someone to the position.
sen.cmt: 訳文をより読みやすく書換えました。
sen.e: Having seen the process of becoming a tenka-bito, it is clear that a combination of circumstances and chance, would raise someone to the position.

sen.j: 本人たちの努力やその合目的的な判断が実を結んだことも多々あったにちがいないが、本人たちにも計算できなかったような偶発的要素も大きく作用していることもあり、運・ツキはなおさら能力以上に重要である。
sen.e: In fact, in many cases, their efforts and reasonable judgments brought about fruitful results, however, it is also true that some accidental factors that they did not even expect often influenced them, which suggests that these accidental factors are also one of the important factors that can determine their success.

In fact, in many cases, their efforts and reasonable judgments brought about fruitful results, however, it is also true that some accidental factors that they did not even expect often influenced them, which suggests that these accidental factors are also important factors that can determine their success.
sen.cmt: these accidental factors とあるため、one of the important factors を important factors に訂正しました。
sen.e: In fact, in many cases, their efforts and reasonable judgments brought about fruitful results, however, it is also true that some accidental factors that they did not even expect often influenced them, which suggests that these accidental factors are also important factors that can determine their success.

tit.e: The end of the history of tenka-bito
The end of the tenka-bito's history
tit.cmt: the history of tenka-bito を the tenka-bito's history に変更しました。
tit.e: The end of the tenka-bito's history

sen.j: 慶長8年（1603年）、家康は征夷大将軍の宣下を受け、江戸に幕府を開いた。
sen.e: In 1603, Ieyasu received the proclamation of seiitaishogun and started the Edo bakufu.
In 1603, Ieyasu received the proclamation of seiitaishogun and started the Edo bakufu.
In 1603, Ieyasu received the proclamation of seiitaishogun and started the Edo bakufu.

sen.j: それ以後、最後の将軍徳川慶喜まで15代、約260年間続いた。
sen.e: Since then, the Edo bakufu lasted for 260 years until the time of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
The Edo bakufu lasted for 15 successive reigns, some 260 years, until the time of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 不要な Since then, を削除、約260年の約 (some) を補いました。また、訳漏れを補いました（15代 15 succesive reigns）
sen.e: The Edo bakufu lasted for 15 successive reigns, some 260 years, until the time of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: しかし、黒船来航で攘夷・尊王思想が高まり、最終的には徳川幕府は倒壊し、700年近く続いた武家政権は幕を閉じた。
sen.e: However, with the arrival of the Black Ships, thought of reverence for the emperor became dominant and led to the fall of the Tokugawa shogunate after 700 years of is governance.
However, with the arrival of the Black Ships, reverence for the Emperor became dominant and led to the fall of the Tokugawa shogunate after 700 years of government.
sen.cmt: 不要な thought of を削除しました。
sen.e: However, with the arrival of the Black Ships, reverence for the Emperor became dominant and led to the fall of the Tokugawa shogunate after 700 years of government.

sen.j: 武家政治は大政奉還－王政復古－明治維新という形で終わる。
sen.e: Samurai governement ended as the society saw the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), then the restoration of Imperial rule, and finally the Meiji restoration; after that, Japan took the path for the modernization.
Samurai government ended as society saw the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), then the restoration of Imperial rule, and finally the Meiji restoration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 また the society の the を削除しました。
sen.e: Samurai government ended as society saw the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), then the restoration of Imperial rule, and finally the Meiji restoration.

sen.j: そして、日本は近代化の道をたどっていく。
sen.e: After that, Japan took the path for the modernization.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After that, Japan took the path for the modernization.

sen.j: それと同時に、武士階級そのものも存在理由がなくなり、士農工商（四民）の封建的身分制度が撤廃され、武士の消滅とともに、天下人の歴史も終焉した。
sen.e: At the same time, the existance of the samurai class lost its significance and led to the abolishment of the feudal system called Shinokosho (hereditary four-status order consisting of warrior-rulers, peasants, artisans, and merchants) and the history of tenka-bito also came to an end as samurai disappeared.

At the same time, the existence of the samurai class lost its significance and led to the abolishment of the feudal system called Shinokosho (hereditary four-status order consisting of warrior-rulers, peasants, artisans, and merchants) and the history of the tenka-bito also came to an end as the samurai disappeared.
sen.cmt: 文末の tenka-bito と samurai に the を補足しました。
sen.e: At the same time, the existence of the samurai class lost its significance and led to the abolishment of the feudal system called Shinokosho (hereditary four-status order consisting of warrior-rulers, peasants, artisans, and merchants) and the history of the tenka-bito also came to an end as the samurai disappeared.
